Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
Technical Description: The goal of this project is to develop the epitaxial technology to grow metamorphic antimonide-based materials and study their structural, optical and electrical properties. The fundamental absorption edge of these semiconductors can vary within a wide spectral range from near to far infrared. Currently the full technological potential of antimonide-based semiconductors cannot be utilized since the direct growth of epitaxial layers is limited by the availability of the binary substrates. The large lattice mismatch between the epitaxial layers and substrate leads to high densities of crystalline defects. The approach of compositionally graded buffer layers can address this issue based on understanding of the dislocation formation and dislocation motion in soft antimonide materials. The critical factor is strain relief in the compositionally graded buffer layer confining the network of misfit dislocations in the transitional region near the substrate. The lattice constant becomes truly a design parameter unveiling fundamental advantages offered by antimonide semiconductors. The experimental studies of the optical and electrical properties of narrow bandgap bulk materials and heterostructures grown on top of metamorphic buffers are necessary to develop the fundamental knowledge of the properties of this new class of semiconductors.
Non-technical Description: Antimonide-based narrow bandgap semiconductors are important materials for development of the efficient photonic and electronic devices which are suitable for a variety of industrial and military applications. The potential of this class of semiconductors can be fully utilized when the lattice constant of the device heterostructure becomes one of the design parameters. The projected studies are directly related to the problem of integration of electronics and photonics devices. The societal impact of the research is amplified by outreach activities. Undergraduate and graduate students working on development and implementation of various optical sensors will be able to utilize novel materials with rare optical and electrical properties for their original designs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The device quality narrow-gap InAsSb bulk alloys and InAsSb-based short-period strained layer superlattices (SLS) with lattice constants up to 3.3 % greater than that of GaSb substrate have been grown by Molecular Beam Epitaxy.  A lattice constant not restructed by that of the substrate becomes a design parameter which opened up another dimension in parameter space for engineering material properties: we demonstrated quality InAsSb alloys with high Sb compositons for low temperature energy gaps as low as 90 meV and 50 meV for InAsSb-based SLS with short cell periods for efficient tunneling of minority holes across layers and long diffusion length in the growth direction.

Compared to HgCdTe-based materials, Sb-based III-V compound heterostructures with InAsSb absorber and (Al,Ga)InSb barriers can be designed with a complete absence of valence band offset for unimpeded hole diffusion across the heterostructure. At the same time the energy band difference at the heterostructure interface creates an electron barrier with complete blocking if the electron transport.  This approach makes  it possible to separate optically generated carriers and/or to confine electrically injected carriers  solely  by energy band enginneiring rather than to rely on barriers created with p- and n-type doping.  The heterobarrier devices were shown to operate with high performance at significantly higher temperatures eliminating the need in compressors and cryogenic liquids, making it possible to operate with multistage thermoelectric coolers for major cost reduction. 

Conventional Sb-based SLS including InGaSb/InAs and InAs/InAsSb cells grown with lattice-matching to GaSb substrates have material composition ranges dictated by maximum strain. The latter implies certain limits on minimal layer thickness in SLS cells for the layer with holes for strain compensation which in turn leads to hole confinement in a single layer of the cell. Respectively, the conventional SLS materials grown with lattice matching to the substrate are set back compared to bulk alloys such as HgCdTe or bulk InAsSb where hole transport is unimpeded and optical absorption is 2-3 times greater due to 100 % electron hole wavefunction overlap.  

The short-period SLS InAsSb-based materials grown on metamorphic buffers were shown to have up to 95 % electron-hole wavefunction overlap making them essentially equivalent to bulk alloys. This leads to superior optical absorption of the materials and allows for photodetector designs with higher quantum efficiency and faster resposne time.

In the demonstrated materials and heterobarrier structures the difference in the lattice constants was accomodated with compositionally graded (Al)GaInSb  buffers grown with strain relaxation in a regime that allowed to maintain the epitaxial materials grown on top of the buffers to be unstrained and unrrlaxed with long minority carrier lifetime (0.2 us), high carrier mobility (100,000 cm^2/Vs for electrons and 1000 cm^2/Vs for holes) at T = 77K.  The barrier heterostructures with energy gaps below 0.1 eV,  a bulk-like absorption spectrum and a 9 um hole diffusion of length at T = 77K were obtained which make it possible to develop efficient optoelectronic  devices for long -wave infrared wavelength region based on III-V compounds with a fast (~ 1 ns) response time.
